title: Cartoon Girl sells for $37m as protests intensify in Hong Kong
text:
As violence escalated in Hong Kong over the weekend with protesters starting fires and throwing petrol bombs, and police responding with tear gas, a roomful of Asia's elite gathered to bid on art and wine.

The venue was the city's convention centre near where the protests took place, part of Sotheby's five-day marathon, which continues through Tuesday. The sales include 20 live auctions and are targeting more than $498 million.

Yoshitomo Nara's Knife Behind Back fetched a record price. Sotheby's

The highlight of Sunday's contemporary art auction was a world record for Japanese artist Yoshitomo Nara, whose painting of a cute but menacing cartoon girl, Knife Behind Back, sold for $US24.9 million ($37 million).

The jewels, wines, watches and fine art on offer this week represented a jarring contrast to the events in the streets.

Video footage showed a bloodied taxi driver dragged out of his car and stomped by a group of protesters after the vehicle hit some of them. On Friday, a 14-year-old boy was shot and injured, the second such incident of the week, during a scuffle between a plain-clothes police officer and demonstrators who had attacked his car.
description: Art auctions in Hong Kong have reported strong interest and record prices, unaffected by the violent events in the streets.
